beats.reasoning: Intro low‑energy section, building tension with subtle, cool wash. To avoid a robotic feel and keep the opening calm, the first beat remains breathing room with no active effects.

Beat 2/199 falls in the very early intro (~1% of the track) where energy is low and the focus is on subtle tension buildup. Following professional rules, we avoid any motion or VFX at this point to keep the atmosphere dark and breathing space before the first dramatic changes on downbeat 1.

At ~1% of the track, the intro is building tension; a subtle wave motion on a single light gives a gentle build without overwhelming the calm early section. The medium energy and high‑band dominance justify a mild motion, while keeping the VFX off for the intro.

At ~2% into the track the intro is still building tension; the beat 4/199 falls on a non‑downbeat and the energy is only medium. To preserve breathing room and avoid over‑lighting the early section, we leave this beat empty per the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro‑phase guidelines.

Beat 5 is in the intro where the music is still building tension; energy is only medium and the section is still calm. To maintain a subtle atmosphere and allow space before the build, we keep this beat without active lighting, following the 60‑70% sync rule for breathing room.

Beat 6/199 sits in the very early intro phase (~3% of the track). Intro sections should start subtle and build gradually; the medium energy and high‑band presence warrant a gentle motion to support the vocals without a dramatic impact. A single moving head with a soft circular rotation, a static cool color and a subtle ping‑pong intensity keeps the atmosphere restrained yet engaging.

Beat 7/199 falls early in the intro, a low‑energy, high‑band section where subtle motion builds tension without overwhelming the vocals. A single moving head with a gentle wave motion and a cool static color provides a subtle wash that supports the warm vocals while keeping the atmosphere calm. No VFX or strobe is used to preserve the intro’s intro‑tension feel.

Beat 8/199 is in the early intro where energy is only medium and no key lyrical or drop moment occurs; to follow the 60‑70% sync rule and avoid over‑lighting during a calm build‑up, this beat remains silent for breathing room.

Beat 9 is still in the intro phase with medium energy but overall low intensity; to build tension gradually we leave this beat empty for breathing room, reserving effects for the first full bar or beat 1 of a phrase.

At ~5% of the track this is still the intro; energy is medium but the section is establishing tension. A single moving head with a subtle rotate motion and steady color keeps the mood restrained while satisfying the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 11/199 falls in the early intro where the music is still building tension. Professional practice calls for minimal lighting—soft, cool washes—so we leave this beat as breathing room to avoid over‑stimulation, keeping sync to 60‑70% overall.

At ~6% of the track the energy is medium but the intro is still building tension; the beat falls in a low‑energy section where subtlety and breathing room are preferred. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and professional intro guidelines, this beat remains silent to allow gradual build‑up.

Beat 13/199 is within the opening 6% of the track, an intro that should remain subtle and build tension gradually. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro guidelines, this beat is kept as breathing room to avoid over‑lighting and allow the music to establish its mood.

At ~7% of the track the intro is building tension; a subtle wave on a single moving head with cool static color and gentle intensity variation supports the vocals without overwhelming. Beat 14 remains part of the 60‑70% sync rhythm while keeping the effect low‑key for breathing space.

Beat 15 is still within the intro, so we keep the lighting subtle but begin to introduce motion. A single moving‑head (key 2) with a gentle wave (MotionEffect 3) and a static cool colour (ColorEffect 1) provides a soft wash that follows the medium, mid‑dominant energy without overwhelming the vocals. Spectrum‑based intensity (IntensityEffect 1) adds dynamic variation while keeping the overall feel restrained.

At ~8 % of the track this is still in the intro phase where we want a subtle, cool wash and gradual build‑up. The energy is only medium and the section is pre‑drop, so keeping this beat off maintains breathing room and follows the 60‑70 % sync rule.

At ~8% of the track the intro is building gently; medium energy with high‑band dominance and vocal lyric cues call for a subtle motion to add texture without overtener. A single moving head with a gentle wave keeps the lighting in sync about 60‑70% of beats while maintaining the cool, calm intro atmosphere.

At beat 18 in the intro (~9% of the track), energy is medium with a high‑frequency emphasis and vocal lyrics present. To build tension subtly, a single moving head with a gentle wave motion and a static cool wash keeps the atmosphere calm while providing subtle motion, aligning with the intro‑build rule.

Beat 19/199 falls in the early intro where the energy is medium but still building; I opt for a subtle laser fan that adds gentle motion without overwhelming the calm atmosphere. The blue static color supports the cool intro vibe while a PingPongIntensity keeps the light breathing in sync with the beat.

Beat 20/199 lands in the early intro (~10% of the track) with medium energy but a mid‑band focus and no immediate lyric hook. To follow the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro convention of subtle, cool washes, this beat is kept as breathing room to build tension gradually.

Beat 21 is early in a verse with medium energy and high‑band emphasis; a subtle rotating wash supports the vocals without overwhelming the mix, following the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping the energy building.

This beat falls in a medium‑energy verse with vocal support. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a subtle single‑light motion keeps the groove without overpowering the vocals. A rotating beam with a warm static color and ping‑pong intensity provides breathing room while still adding movement.
Verse segment with medium energy and vocal focus; a gentle wave motion on a single light supports the vocals without overwhelming, following the 60–70% sync rule.

This beat falls in a medium‑energy verse with high‑frequency content, so a gentle wave motion on a single light supports the vocals without overpowering the mix. A static warm color and spectrum‑based intensity keep the wash subtle, following the rule to avoid strobe or intense VFX in calm sections.

Beat 25 falls in the middle of a verse with medium energy and warm vocal emphasis; a gentle wave motion on a single light supports the vocals without overwhelming the mix. A static warm color and spectrum‑based intensity keep the lighting subtle yet dynamic, fitting the verse’s supportive role.

Beat 26/199 falls in the verse section with medium energy and high‑frequency content, so a gentle, supportive motion is appropriate. A single moving head with a subtle wave motion and warm static color will enhance the vocals without overpowering the mix, following the 60–70% sync rule and keeping the verse calm.

Beat 27 falls in a verse with medium energy and strong vocal emphasis. A subtle rotating single light provides supportive motion without overpowering the section, adhering to the 60‑70% sync rule and maintaining breathing room.
Beat 28 falls in the verse with medium energy and high‑band dominance; a gentle wave on a single moving head keeps the mood supportive without overwhelming vocals, following the 60–70% sync rule.

Beat 29 is a downbeat in the early verse with low energy; a gentle wave motion from a single moving head supports the vocals without overwhelming. A warm static color and a subtle ping‑pong intensity keep the lighting subtle yet present, following the 60‑70% sync rule while respecting the verse structure.

Beat 30 falls in a mid‑verse with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals; we use a gentle wave on a single moving head to support the vocal line, plus a subtle laser cone for ambient movement, keeping the mood restrained and aligned with verse conventions.

Beat 31 falls in the verse with medium energy and dominant mid frequencies; a gentle wave on a single moving head provides support for vocals without overwhelming the mix. A static warm color keeps the wash neutral while a wave‑intensity effect adds subtle motion synchronized with the beat.

Verse 32/199 is a high‑energy line in the early verse; we add a subtle rotating beam to support vocals without overwhelming. A single moving head (key 2) with Wave motion and a warm static color keeps the beat lively yet restrained, following the 60‑70% sync rule.
Beat 33 falls within a mid‑energy verse with no dramatic lyric change or build‑up cue, so a quiet moment provides breathing room and follows the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 34 lies in a medium‑energy verse with high‑band emphasis; a subtle Wave motion on a single moving head supports the vocal line without overpowering the mix. A PingPongColor and WaveIntensity add gentle dynamic contrast while keeping the lighting breathing for the rest of the section.

Beat 35 falls in the verse section with medium energy and high‑band vocals—ideal for a subtle motion to support the singers without overwhelming. A single‑head moving light with a gentle Wave motion and warm static color provides breathing room while still keeping the stage alive.

Beat 36 sits in a mid‑verse with medium energy and vocal emphasis; a subtle motion on a single moving head keeps the vocals in focus without overwhelming the calm section. A gentle wave motion with a warm static color and moderate spectrum‑based intensity supports the lyric flow.

Beat 37 falls in the verse section (~18% of the track). Energy is high but still a support section, so we use a subtle moving‑head wave to complement the vocals without a full drop. No VFX are added, following the rule that VFX only appear on drops or climactic moments.

Beat 38 falls within a high‑energy verse where the vocal line is prominent; we keep the lighting subtle to support the vocals. A single moving head with a wave motion on beat 1 syncs to the bass, while a warm static color and ping‑pong intensity keep the effect gentle yet dynamic, respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 39 sits in the middle of a verse with moderate energy and repeated vocals; we use a subtle wave motion to keep the light supporting the singer without overwhelming, following the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style restraint.

Beat 40/199 falls in the middle of a verse with medium energy and no key lyric or build‑up cue. Following the 60‑70 % sync rule and verse guidelines, this beat is left breathing room and silent to support the vocals without overwhelming them.
Beat 41 is a medium‑energy verse moment; to support vocals we use a gentle rotating wash with warm color and wave‑intensity, keeping it subtle per verse guidelines.

Beat 42 falls in the early verse (≈21% of the track) where vocal support is key; the high energy suggests a bit more movement but still restrained. A gentle rotating single‑head with warm static color and alternating intensity provides a supportive wash without overpowering the vocals, adhering to the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 43 sits in the early verse (≈21% of the track) with medium energy and vocal lyrics; professional rules recommend a subtle, supportive wash rather than a full blast. A single moving head performing a gentle Wave with a static warm color and spectrum‑based intensity keeps the stage alive without overpowering the vocals, providing a 60‑70% sync rate while respecting the 30‑40% breathing room rule.

Beat 44 falls in a verse with high energy and mid‑band prominence, so a subtle motion effect supports the vocals without overwhelming. A single moving head with a Wave motion, static color, and ping‑pong intensity gives rhythmic breathing room while keeping the energy moderate.

Beat 45 falls in the first verse (~22% of the track) where vocals are prominent but the section remains supportive rather than climactic. To honor the 60‑70% sync rule while keeping the energy moderate, a single moving head with a gentle Wave motion, a warm static color, and a ping‑pong intensity keeps the lights in sync with the vocal line without overpowering the mix.

Beat 46 falls in a verse with medium energy and sustained vocals; a gentle wave motion on a single moving head supports the lyrics without overwhelming the mix, following the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping the build low before the chorus.

Beat 47 falls in the early verse with medium energy and vocal lyrics; a gentle, low‑level movement supports the vocals without overpowering them. A single moving head using a subtle wave motion, warm static color, and mild intensity ping‑pong keeps the groove alive while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 48 falls in the middle of the verse with medium energy and high‑frequency dominance, so a subtle motion that supports the vocal line is appropriate. A single moving head with a gentle Wave motion and warm static color keeps the atmosphere calm yet dynamic, following the 60‑70% sync rule for breathing room.

Beat 49 is a medium‑energy verse moment; to support vocals we use a subtle wave motion on a single moving head with a warm static color, keeping the intensity gentle. The effect is kept minimal to preserve breathing room while still marking the beat.

Beat 50/199 sits in a mid‑energy verse with strong vocal emphasis; the light should support the lyric without dominating. A gentle wave motion on a single moving head, paired with a warm static color and a ping‑pong intensity, gives subtle dynamism while keeping the stage calm and in sync with the 60‑70% rule.

Beat 51 falls within a high‑energy verse where the vocal line is still building. To support the vocals without overwhelming, a single moving‑head light uses a gentle Wave motion with a static warm color and subtle intensity modulation, following the 60‑70% sync rule for breathing room.

Beat 52 sits in the middle of a high‑energy verse; we want a supportive, non‑overwhelming laser fan to accent the vocals while keeping the mix balanced. A single MULTI_LIGHT_GROUP with a LaserFan, static warm color and alternating beams provides motion and contrast without strobe fatigue.

Beat 53 falls within a mid‑verse with medium energy and lyrical content; a subtle Wave motion on a single moving head keeps the light supporting vocals without overpowering the section. A warm static color and gentle ping‑pong intensity add subtle motion while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Medium‑energy verse lyric, so a subtle wave motion on a single moving head supports the vocals without overwhelming; a warm static color keeps the wash gentle and the intensity is kept low with pingpong intensity for breathing space.

Beat 56 falls in a verse with medium energy and vocal lyrics; a gentle wave motion on a single moving head supports the vocals without overwhelming the section. Beat 57 falls in the verse at ~28% of the track; energy is high but the section should stay supportive. A single moving head with a gentle Wave motion and warm static color provides vocal support while keeping the mood calm, respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

A single moving head with a subtle wave motion and a warm static color provides a low‑intensity wash that follows the 60–70% sync rule while giving breathing room on other beats.

At beat 61 the track is in a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency elements; adding a subtle laser cone with dynamic colors and alternating intensity supports the rising intensity without overwhelming the vocals, fitting the 60‑70 % sync rule.

Beat 62 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy but a high‑frequency dominant band. To gradually raise intensity without over‑stimulation, a multi‑light laser cone with dynamic per‑beam color and a wave‑intensity pattern provides a subtle yet escalating visual cue that supports the vocals and anticipates the upcoming chorus.

At beat 63 the track is in a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency elements. A single laser cone with random per‑beam colors and alternating intensity gives subtle motion that follows the vocal line without overwhelming the section, aligning with the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 64 sits in the build‑up phase before the chorus, so we add subtle laser motion and a wave on a single moving head to ramp up intensity without overwhelming. At beat 65/199 the track is in a pre‑chorus build‑up: medium energy, high‑band emphasis, and vocals are active.  A LaserFan (MotionEffect 2) with dynamic colors (ColorEffect 2) and alternating intensity (IntensityEffect 3) will increase visual intensity without overpowering, following the 60‑70% sync rule and avoiding VFX at this non‑drop moment.

Beat 66 falls in the build‑up phase (~33% of the track) with high energy and a dominant high‑frequency band, so a laser cone adds forward momentum while still keeping the scene from blowing up. This keeps 60‑70% of beats active without overwhelming the moment.

Beat 72 is in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency content, so we add a subtle laser motion to increase intensity without a full drop. Beat 73 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up; medium energy and high‑frequency content call for a gentle motion that supports the vocals without overpowering. Beat 74 falls in the build‑up / pre‑chorus where energy is medium and the lyric is steady. Beat 77 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency emphasis; a modest laser cone can raise intensity without full drop force. Beat 78 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency content, and vocals are present. Beat 79 is a high‑energy build‑up moment with active vocals; we use a subtle wave motion on a single moving head to add motion and a laser fan on the multi‑head array to increase intensity, keeping the effect below full drop level as per pre‑chorus guidelines.

Beat 80/199 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up; medium energy with high‑band dominance and vocal lyrics suggest a gradual lift. Beat 81 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy, high‑frequency dominance and vocal lyrics, so we add subtle motion and laser light to gradually raise intensity without full drop theatrics. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and keeps VFX reserved for the climax.

This beat falls in the build‑up; energy is medium but dominant high, so a subtle laser fan adds forward motion without overwhelming the vocals. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a single multi‑light group provides breathing room elsewhere while still building intensity.

Beat 83 is part of the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and mid‑band dominance; we use a gentle rotating motion to increase tension without overwhelming the vocals. A single moving‑head light with a subtle color wash and mild intensity pulsing provides contrast and supports the lyric line, keeping the 60‑70% sync rule and avoiding over‑stimulation.

Beat 84 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up where energy is rising but still moderate; a subtle laser cue with gentle motion supports the vocals without overwhelming the section. In the pre‑chorus build‑up at beat 85/199 the track is high‑energy and mid‑band dominated, but not yet the drop. A single laser fan with a steady color and moderate intensity provides a rising visual cue without over‑stimulation, following the 60‑70 % sync rule.

Beat 86 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with high energy and a dominant high‑frequency line. To gradually raise intensity, we use a laser cone for dramatic visual weight, a rotating head for rhythmic motion, and a wave‑moving single head for bass sync, all while keeping colors warm and intensity dynamic but not overpowering.

Beat 87/199 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency vocal line, so a subtle but growing effect is appropriate. Beat 88/199 falls in a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑bass emphasis. According to the 60‑70% sync rule we add a subtle motion effect—Wave—to lift the intensity without full glare, using a warm static color to support vocals.
Pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑band vocals; we add a rotating single‑head to accent the vocal line and a laser fan for rising intensity while keeping VFX off.

Beat 90 sits in the build‑up section with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals; a subtle moving‑head wave keeps the audience engaged without going full drop. Beat 91 falls in the chorus drop with high energy and vocal lyrics, making it an ideal moment for dramatic lighting. We use a VFX group for a simultaneous burst, a multi‑light laser cone to accent high‑frequency melody lines, and a single‑light wave to match the bass hits, providing variety while keeping breathing room on other beats.

Beat 92 falls in the chorus drop where the energy peaks; we use a VFX burst, laser cone, rotating single light and ping‑pong single light to create a big, dynamic statement that supports the vocal line and satisfies the 60‑70% sync rule.

High‑energy drop with key lyric, so we enable a full VFX burst and synchronized multi‑beam lasers. VFX group 0 delivers a simultaneous effect, while groups 4 and 5 provide complementary LaserCone and LaserFan motion with color and intensity variations to support vocals and maintain 60‑70% sync.

Beat 94/199 sits in the chorus/drop, but the energy reads medium, so we use a moderate mix of laser and moving‑head effects to maintain build without over‑saturation. A LaserCone on the multi‑light array keeps the visual intensity high, while a Wave motion on a single head provides rhythmic support under the vocal line.

This beat falls in the chorus with medium energy but still carries a key lyric; a subtle laser fan plus a rotating single light provide support without overwhelming. The effects align with the 60‑70 % sync rule and maintain contrast by adding motion and color while keeping intensity balanced.

Beat 96/199 falls in the chorus with medium energy; we add a laser fan to maintain energy without overloading the mix. A dynamic color and intensity pattern keeps the visual interest while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 97 occurs in the high‑energy chorus drop; we activate a VFX burst and synchronized laser fan to emphasize the climax while keeping 30% breathing room. The single moving head adds rotating motion to match the bass, and the multi‑light laser fan provides bright, random color beams.

Beat 98 sits on a high‑energy chorus downbeat, so we trigger a full‑scale visual moment: a simultaneous VFX burst for impact, a LaserCone beam sweep for the main hook, and a Wave motion on a single head to emphasize the vocal line. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and keeps the energy high while supporting the lyrics.

Beat 99 falls in the middle of the chorus/drop, a high‑energy section but not the initial downbeat. To maintain 60‑70% sync while providing visual punch, we add a LaserFan sweep on the multi‑light array and a Wave motion on a single moving head, supporting the vocal line without over‑strobing.

Beat 100/199 falls inside the chorus section, yet the energy is medium and the lyric line is repetitive, so we keep the intensity moderate. Beat 101 falls in the chorus drop where energy is high overall but this particular beat is medium‑level, so we use a mix of lasers and a supportive single‑head wave to keep the momentum without overwhelming the vocals. The VFX groups stay off, and the motion, color and intensity are all activated according to the professional rules for this section.

Beat 102/199 occurs at the start of the chorus/drop with high energy and vocal lyric, so we use dramatic effects. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule while providing visual impact.

Beat 103/199 sits in the mid‑song chorus with high energy and vocal lyrics, so it’s an ideal point for a full‑scale visual burst. Beat 106 sits in the middle of a high‑energy chorus, so we use a burst of synchronized effects—a laser fan, a moving wave beam, and a VFX simultaneous burst—to emphasize the drop while keeping the mix balanced. The beat is not a strict downbeat, so the VFX is kept simple and the motion effects are moderate to avoid strobe fatigue.

Beat 107/199 falls in the chorus with medium energy but still high‑band emphasis; a subtle yet dynamic laser fan keeps the energy without over‑stimulation, supporting the vocal line. No VFX is used to avoid cluttering this already intense section.

At 54% of the track this beat sits in the chorus drop; medium energy still warrants visual support but not a full blaze. Beat 109/199 sits in the chorus drop with high energy and lyrics; we trigger a full visual impact. Beat 110 is a strong downbeat in a high‑energy chorus/drop. Following industry practice, we use a VFX burst for drama and a synchronized laser cone to accent the bass hits, giving a clear visual climax while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 111 sits in the chorus with medium energy but high‑frequency dominance and lyrical content, so we keep the intensity high without a full VFX blast. A laser fan keeps the beam energy while a rotating wave adds motion, respecting the 60‑70% sync rule and avoiding strobe‑like repetition.

Beat 114/199 sits at the peak of the chorus/drop with medium‑to‑high energy and sustained high‑frequency content. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, this beat receives a VFX burst, laser cone, and a rotating single‑head to accentuate the drop and support vocal emphasis.

Beat 115/199 lands in the chorus/drop where energy peaks and vocal intensity is high; professional practice calls for dramatic, multi‑layered lighting. Beat 116/199 falls in the chorus/drop section (high energy, mid‑band dominant, lyrics present). Beat 122/199 falls in the chorus/drop phase (~61% of the track) with medium energy but high‑band presence and active vocals. Beat 123/199 follows a high‑energy drop and sits in the chorus. Medium energy and dominant high band call for a continuation of movement without the full VFX burst, allowing the crowd to stay engaged while providing breathing room next beats.
